title: PSYC BC1101 STATISTICS
text:
Professor: Dr. Rob Brotherton
Email: rbrother@barnard.edu
Office Hours: Wednesday 4–5pm, 415M Milbank
Lecture hours: Tuesday & Thursday, 10:10am–11:25am
Lecture venue: 207 Milbank Hall

title: PSYC BC1101 STATISTICS
text:
Course Overview
This course, required for the psychology major, provides an introduction to statistical methods commonly used in psychological research. Topics include measures of central tendency and variability, probability and sampling, confidence intervals and hypothesis testing, t-test and analysis of variance, correlation and regression. In addition to learning the conceptual and mathematical underpinnings of these techniques, you will learn to calculate and interpret statistics with reference to real-world contexts and research questions typical in psychological research. The course includes recitation meetings that provide instruction in the analysis of psychological data using the R statistical software package commonly used by behavioral science researchers.
The course is designed to fulfill these goals:

Understand what statistics are, and why and when they are needed
Translate observations about the world into statistical statements and questions
Learn how statistical methods are used to test psychological hypotheses
Use statistical software (R) to describe, visualize, analyze, and report data

Making statistics

“In the United States today half of all children (35.6 million) live in a household where a parent or other adult uses tobacco, drinks heavily or uses illicit drugs”

title: BC1101
text:
Measuring things
Constructs & operational definitions

Construct: Extroversion
Operational definition: Big 5 questions
Construct: Intelligence
Operational definition: IQ test
Construct: Height
Operational definition: How far the top of your head is from the floor according to a tape measure

title: BC1101
text:
Measuring things

Operationalizing variables

Usually more than one way we could go about measuring & recording data
Result in different types of data, and potentially different applicable analyses
How to decide on operational definition?

Aspects to consider:

Type of variable (discrete / continuous)
Scale of measurement (nominal / ordinal / interval / ratio)

title: BC1101

Lectures

Topics covered:
Basic issues:

Terminology, variables & measurement

Descriptive statistics:

Frequency, central tendency, variability, z-scores

Inferential statistics:

Probability, sampling; hypothesis testing
\(t\)-tests; ANOVA; Correlation & regression

Logical progression

title: BC1101
text:
Recitation

Practical application of stats to data

Problem Sets
Using R markdown
Show code—how you worked out answers
Work on .Rmd in RStudio Cloud
Upload “knitted” .pdf to Canvas

title: BC1101
text:
Recitation

Grading problem sets

0, 1, or 2 points
0 = No submission, 1 = Incomplete, 2 = Valid attempt
Wrong answers ≠ lower grade
Deadline: 5pm Eastern day of recitation

title: BC1101
text:
Exams

3 multiple choice exams

Each covers around 1/3 of the material
60 multiple choice questions
60 minutes
Only lecture material, not R
Non-cumulative
Except inasmuch as later concepts rely on ones introduced earlier

Some questions will involve sums, but only simple ones you can do on paper

title: BC1101
text:
Final grades

Final grade

20% Lecture / discussion forum engagement
20% Problem Sets
60% 3 multiple choice exams (20% each)

title: BC1101
text:
Math

Statistics requires basic math skills
E.g. order of operations

Parentheses
Exponents (like squaring/square root)
Multiplication & division
Summation
Addition & subtraction

title: BC1101
text:
Math

Summation

Symbol \(\Sigma\) (Greek letter Sigma) means add up a set of scores
Summation is done after operations in parentheses, squaring, and multiplication or division, but before other addition or subtraction
E.g… Scores: 2, 4, 7


\[\Sigma X = ? \\
\Sigma X + 1 = ? \\
\Sigma(X + 1) = ?\]

title: BC1101
text:
Math

Algebra

Rearranging equations
E.g.


\[\begin{align}12 &= 7 + X \\ X &= ? \end{align}\]

Advantages

Free
Can do stuff other stats software can only dream of
Keeps a record of what you do
Pretty graphs
Feel like a super cool hacker
Pirate jokes
Good for your career
